description.text: 4 NiMH cells just aren't enough to power the arduino and sensors that I want to use. 5 might do. I designed this 5 AA cell holder to hold rechargeable cells and power my Arduino projects. I first tried using the well designed battery pack - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5079 - but had problems with the clearance necessary to allow for the bolt head contacts. The bolts and washers are additional components that I don't want to have to use for batteries. My design uses solid copper wire for the battery contacts and interconnects. Soldering the wire ends is optional and I imagine will increase the physical lifetime of the pack. The wires should be wrapped twice through the wall to give good contact with the battery. The wire channel design has a land to cause the copper to extend out to press against the battery. There are wire channels on the inside and outside of the box to correctly align the wires and keep the package neat. The alternate design has some corners built into the top to center an arduino above the battery box and hold it steady. It was designed for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8706 this Arduino holder, which I use to protect my furniture from the pins at the bottom of the arduino, and the contacts from short circuiting. The packs can be stacked to produce a split power system, or 12V

To Assemble: (with pix at http://robotranch.org/blog/archives/251 ) I used solid cat-5 twisted pair, since I have a box of it sitting around. Cut a bit more than foot and pull out the twisted pairs. Pick a color. Untwist it about half way and poke the dark strand through a pass-through hole in one side of the pack. Pull the wire through and press it in the wire channel. Strip the wire at the point of the farthest contact hole (2nd hole from end). You'll want the wire to be insulated up to the point where it enters the box. Then thread the wire through the holes twice, carefully pulling it taut. It's possible to pull apart the copper wire after it's been bent a few times, so be a bit gentle with it as you work with it. We'll tack the wire to itself with a bit of solder when we're done making the contacts. Cut the small end down to about 3" past the end of the twist. Strip it and thread it through the opposite corner as the first. Strip some more of the wire maybe 8 inch pieces. Make a U and pass the two wires through the next two wire holes - at the bottom. On the inside, pass it up and through the top holes. Pass it down the outside, and back up through the inside again, making a double loop. Repeat for the remaining pairs to complete the interconnects. Dab a bit of solder on each of the bottom holes where the wires are entering the pack. This will physically solidify and improve the connection. Take care not to burn the insulation on the ground wire. This could cause a short circuit. Also, don't heat the wire too long, as the plastic could melt. Optionally, you can connect a power connector, or just strip the wires and poke them into a breadboard or Vin/Gnd. I snap off a pair of pins and solder the ends to keep the wires apart and make a clean, easy connection to Vin/Gnd on the Arduino.

A twin rotor animated helicopter pull, push, downhill toy. The front and rear rotors spin as this toy is pushed, pulled or sent down a hill, in front/rear true counter rotating fashion (I have an aviation background, sigh...). Video of prototype is here: https://youtu.be/erEuyxCtarI. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10% with exceptions

Notes: Supports are optional, depending on your printer and settings, for printing "Chassis.stl", "Nose.stl", "Fuselage.stl" and "Tail.stl". My prototypes printed to my satisfaction (with minor filing and sanding) without supports.

Study "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl". Supports are optional, depending on your printer and settings, for printing "Chassis.stl", "Nose.stl", "Fuselage.stl" and "Tail.stl". My prototypes printed fine without supports.
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.
Place wide rubber bands around the circumference of all wheels for traction.
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".  Start by assembling all axles and gears into "Chassis.stl" except for the rotors and their gears.  Next, attach "Fuselage.stl" onto "Chassis.stl", then add the rotors and their gears, and finally, attach "Nose.stl" and "Tail.stl" onto "Chassis.stl".
Apply light machine oil on the moving parts.
To make a pull toy, slip a length of yarn into the lower front hole in "Nose.stl", tie a large knot, secure it with glue, then pull the yarn back so that the knot rests against the inside of the hole.
Once fully assembled, tested and aligned, a small dot of thick cyanoacrylate glue between the gears and axles will aid in holding the gears in position.
If you desire a more "grandkid / youngster" proof toy, I recommend printing the rotors and axles at 100% infill.
Feel free to comment if you have questions.
Hope you like it!

title: Da vinci 1.0 MK3 alu heatbed upgrade

description.text:
UPDATE 21/02/16 added build list + wiring diagram High-Temperature-Wire-3D-Extruder-Heated-Bed-Cable-16A-Double-Insulated
200988618670 DC to DC 3-32V 5-220V 25A 4 Screw Terminal One Phase SSR Solid State Relay
191657389961 10pcs Spring for 3D Printer Extruder Heated Bed For Ultimaker Makerbot
271544619870 24V 30A psu
311001005100 MK3 3D Printer Heated Bed - 3mm Aluminium PCB Heatbed - 12/24v Heat bed Alu DTEG
262179766916 200x 213 3D Printer Borosilicate Glass Build Plate For Heated Bed RepRap Prusa
161840005009 Single-phase SSR Solid State Relay Radiator Aluminum Heat Sink 125mmx70mmx50mm
231495284363 UPDATE 07/02/16 Added solid state relay,heat-sink,and 30AMP PSU photos. UPDATE 06/12/15 https://youtu.be/worV8h37OJ8 I have upgraded my heated-bed with a 24 volt power supply and solid state relay. The power supply on the DA Vinci was taking far too long to heat to temperature,and timing out sometimes.
The bed now heats up in just over two minutes.
I have 24 volts running on the 12 volt input of mk3 alu heated-bed. The DA Vinci works great with this new heat bed and i don't need to worry about the glass cracking or chipping ever again.
For insulation i have a piece of 3mm cork sandwiched between two MK3 heat-beds,i got them for just over 10 pound each off eBay.
I have two piece of borosilicate glass that i can change out between prints to minimize downtime even further. UPDATE 23/10/15
Added DXF files for laser cutting.
Assemble the laser cut sub assemblies as per the photos,use 5mm acrylic.
Once the two halves of the laser cut acrylic are bonded you will have the equivalent of the 3d printed version.
i used Tensol 12 to bond them together but you can also use super glue. UPDATE 23/10/15
Added 21.5mm middle support for use with the original DA Vinci springs and adjustment wheels. For a three adjuster setup, print x 1 support @21.5mm and x 2 support @37mm..
For a four adjuster setup, print x 2 supports @ 37mm and x 2 supports @48.5mm. This is a DA Vinci 1.0 3d printer heated bed upgrade to allow you to use a rep-rap MK3 alu build plate. This thing was designed out of necessity after my build plate cracked after a year of 3D printing torture ,poor thing sob ,(. Although the DA Vinci printer only uses three adjustment screws there are actually four holes in the z axis support for four adjustment wheels. I have decided to use all four for better support whilst printing. You will need to insulate the z axis support under the build plate with some cork or you can reuse the fiber mat from the original build platform. DXF files coming soon to enable laser cutting for those whose printers have given up the ghost. Has explained in previous posts please turn on build plate pre-heat to prevent your printer firmware timing out on you. Enjoy

description.text: This tool is designed to help you lay out and organize your space without the use of a computer and is part of the Choosing a Space chapter of my new book "The Makerspace Workbench" from Maker Media! Simply print out the graphic to whatever scale you wish, draw the outline of your space, cut out the sample equipment graphics and glue to them to the grid. Easy as that!

This is a template for cutting 8" squares, typically out of patterned papers for Origami where you would like the design to aligned in a specific fashion.

There are 2 spot colors defined in the file - Cut (Red) and Etch (Blue).
I have found that 1/8" frosted acrylic works very well. I recommend the etch be on the frosted side and that the template is used frosted side down. This results in the best visibility of the aligning grid.

title: badBrick - bbBBAUR3PLXPIRBase, PLX PIR + Arduino Base Case

description.text: Base case fits one Parallax PIR sensor and an Arduino UNO R3. This base case slides on, and is a lid to our 9v power Brick. We also have a top cover .STL for this thing over at badbrick.com/catalog The (4) holes on the sides also fit the Lego round shafts in technic kits. Its also designed so that you can attach jumper wires throught the top to connect up something else. If you don't have a 3D printer but you're interested in getting one of these we can print you one at http://www.badbrick.com/catalog

In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings:
Quality: Layer Height = 0.2 and I increase the temp to 240C to let the larger prints fuse better. All other defaults are the same. ** Please note to Maker Ware users. I've downgraded our MW back to 2.1.x and the firmware back to 7.1. For some reason our STLs were not printing correctly with the new 2.2 update. The slicer was printing partial faces that are not in the model.

He has broken just about everything on his at least once, we did have the rear motor mount come apart during flight, I ended up making the plate thicker which later survived a pretty bad crash. author: shmorgan

description.text: Patches and Accessories for Immortan Joe cosplay. The "Chain Holder" still hasn't been perfectly identified in the forums, but this is an approximation of the piece. It is 4 parts and has a back plate so that it can be supported in the plastic chest piece. This part does require a couple bolts and nuts, and a spring. Also needs to be printed with some support matieral. Keypad.stl is a replica of the Nokia keypad that he has on his upper left shoulder. The Sheriff, Sheriff Small, Texas, and Nambia patches are all based off work from the detailed and excellent thread on therpf.com http://www.therpf.com/showthread.php?t=240451&page=37 where people are identifying the correct patches and badges. Although the 3d modeling is my own. These parts should be proper patches, but these 3d printed ones work just as well on a budget. Note that all of these pieces need to be curved. Using a heat gun or hairdryer on the plastic you can heat it up and then get a slight bend it in using some large pvc pipe. Then let it cool and it will hold its shape.

author: ouchered

description.text:
28.10.2015 update:
  • motor fits easily now
  • corners rounded
  • sagging for the screw
  • gear wheels available

    There are already some paste extruder. But i was looking for a handy one that works with the plunger less syringes that are used for air pressure dispensers.

    • It should be cheap, easy to print and build up with easy getable parts.
    The whole tool should fit in a hand, so it can be used like a tattoo maschine. My hope is that some makers or repair cafés could need it to build up smd-boards or repair newer hardware. The first version still need some cutting work with a knife.
    The parts can be printed without support. It´s included if nessasary.
    0.2mm are fine. But 0.3mm will work to.
    Use 3mm skrews or aceton to weld the parts together. I used a cheap set of plastic gear wheels (available at conrad), because of the robustness.
    May be I will design some gear wheels later.

author: Aequa

title: I Ching dice (易經骰子,八卦骰子)

description.text:
The I Ching is most commonly known as an ancient Chinese method of divination. I design an I Ching dice, and simple way to determine an I Ching hexagram using dice.
You need print two dices with black an white. Black dice is mean internal hexagram at the bottom, and white dice is mean external hexagram on the top. You need a normal dice to determine an hexagram line ( yao ) . 易經骰子/八卦骰子
你需要印兩個骰子，一個黑的一個白的，黑的指的是內卦，白的指的是外卦，然後你需要一個普通骰子來決定哪一爻變。注意這是一個很簡略的取卦法，跟正統的取卦法有差距。所以有很多細節是無法得知的。

description.text: This is a photogrammetry scan of a bust of Roman Emperor Antoninus Pius (reg. 138-161). The bust is located in the "Saal der römischen Bildnisse" at  the Glyptothek in Munich (Item Number 337).

I made around 70 photographs from different angles with my smartphone (Oneplus One). After getting bad results in 123d Catch I recently found Memento (now Autodesk ReMake) and had much better succes. I had to stich some areas under the shoulders , but these areas were quite small.

comments.text: With which program did you put the pictures together to the object? I am already looking for a program but Autodesk ReMake / ReCap somehow do not work for me.
comments.author: FelixRau

comments.text: As I described in the "How I designed this" section: I used Autodesk Memento which is the predecessor of ReCap/ReMake. I used the now discontinued 123D Catch App to take the pictures with my phone and just exported them to my PC. The main point to watch out for is that the pictures overlapp significantly and the object doesn't change much (I had problems with scans outside when the sun was blocked by a cloud halfway through taking pictures, or moving objects in the background when it is a large part of the pictureframe,...) Just play around with the program, I didnt get it on the first try either ;-)

title: Caterpillar for RC 1:24 Heng Long Leopard II A5

description.text:
Spare caterpillar for Heng Long Leopard II A5 (also Abrams M1A2) RC tank 1:24
Originally tanks are equipped with rubber caterpillars. Designed to print on 0,2 layer with no support. Use caterpillar_henglong1-24_foroneside.stl file for complete one side. Use connectors to join parts and flatten its ends. Alternatively you can print 72 pcs (for one side) of caterpillar_henglong1-24_1psc.stl and join them all with connectors. This solution is much better in future accidents - if somethin happen with caterpillar you can change only one or more broken links.

Annoyed by your beloved Hakko 808 desoldering gun refusing to stand up for itself? This wall mount holder will hold it for you.  (without melting!  It holds by plastic parts of the body and doesn't get too close to the business end)

There are holes for optional 1/4" (6mm) bolts to stick through the arms to reinforce them.  May not be necessary if your print is strong enough.
Put the gun into the holder by rotating it bit and then letting it go back to vertical in the arms.

Update:  I redesigned this so the slots would slide in to the box easier.  
I realize that this serves no real practicle purpose other than being a conversation piece.  The idea came to me while explaining about "old" computers to my 6 year old daughter.  I told her how we held all our programs on "floppy discs" and how we used a rolodex to keep them sorted.  She didn't know what that was so I did my best to explain that too.  This is partially why I made this, just so I could show her how that all worked while using more modern technology (SD cards).  I also wanted to try and make something with small snap-together parts!  
Perhaps most importantly is simply because I find making things relaxing and it helps me center myself after a stressful day at work.  
Beware: I have yet to actually print this so it may require design changes!  I also included a model of a mock SD card for the unlikely case that you don't have any laying around.
I printed at .200mm and used a raft. It's a tight fit to get the slots in to the box and you may have to file on it just a tiny bit.

title: Mounting plate for screw joints / Kossel 2020

description.text:
I wanted to get rid of all the cables in my little Deltas. The outer plate is designed for a standard ~30mm x ~15mm rocker switch and for a 15/16mm 4-pin XLR connector (aka microphone plug).
The inner mount is for 4mm² luster terminals (insulating screw joints).
I connect them through 30A XT60 connectors, so I can remove both units from the frame if I have to, without desoldering something.
Nothing special, but useful.

This bracket was designed for holding materials from 6 to 25mm thickness.
It could be a glass or chipboard as well.
For clamping used M5x35 screw and M5x5 nut.

This button is for adding a neck strap for your guitar, or other stringed instrument.
It is similar to the ones sold on eBay and the one Martin sells. Test before use! It is your responsibility.
I use, Guitar Savers Premium Strap Locks, from Amazon just to be on the safe side, but the strength and quality of the leather is more important. I get my leather from old belts at the thrift stores. The leather should be about 1/4" MAX thick when folded. Generally real leather is the strongest and longest lasting. Make sure you cannot break it easily, that it is still supple. Try to get belts that are .75" wide to minimize cutting (sharp scissors are enough). I use hole punches from Harbor Freight. Not the greatest. There are leather punches that are better at Michael's and on Amazon. Or you can sharpen the end of a steel or brass tube by grinding a 45-60 degree bevel on the outer edge.

description.text: This is a direct drive extruder for 1.75mm filament. This extruder will work with E3D hotends with push-to-connect fittings on top. I used this drive gear http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XP3NJSE?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage and a 625 bearing for the idler. The stepper mounts with two 10mm m3 screws and one 18mm m3 screw. The rest of the extruder is set up to use 4-40 hardware. The bottom mounting holes are 4mm bore but have a nut trap for a 4-40 nut so you can still use the standard m4 mounting bolts. A 4-40 button cap screw will fit just into the chamfer of the 625 bearing holding it securely in place. If you don't have button cap screws you can print the bearing spacer and use ordinary hardware. If you like to use ptfe tubing to guide filament to the extruder you can print the ptc (push-to-connect) holder for the top of the extruder.

This is an adapter for a guitar pickup button. Generally, because the 1/4" (6mm) plug for the guitar cable goes through the middle, the outer diameter of the strap button is much larger than normal. This makes using a stock guitar strap a pain. You can either cut the button hole bigger, or use an adapter. There are some available commercially, but I think you will find this one adequate, strong and easy to use.
I have gone through several iterations. This one is still in work. Make extras of the little locking clip, strapretnr4b-revNC, until I come up with a way to keep it from getting lost.
To install, slip the larger circle over the pickup button, and pull until the smaller diameter is seated in the pickup button. With the small protrusion pointing up, squeeze the locking clip until the gap closes; push the pointed end down into the larger hole as shown, and the entire clip will go down into the hole. Release the clip and it will seat itself and will not fall out. The entire assembly should be free to rotate without coming off the button.
I designed the to fit the pickup button on a Fender 12 string. It should fit most that look the same. Please let me know if some slight changes will fit more slightly different pickups. As far as I know they are all about the same.
Make sure your pickup is screwed down tight before you start fiddling around. I had to loosen my strings and pull the pickup back through the sound hold to adjust the inner nut. Not fun, especially with a 12 string. (Use an old guitar string to guide it back to the sound hole, and then back out through the end hole on the lower bout if that should occur.)
Still not a bad idea to use rubber strap locks with this setup.
Make sure you test your work before using! You do not want weak parts which equals guitar on the floor. It is your responsibility.
I used Gizmo Dorks transparent ABS which is strong and reliable. You should print slow and use 50-100% fill. The ones here were printed using a .5mm nozzle on a Taz 4, .2mm height, 60% cooling after 5 layers. Cleaning up the holes and locking clip is important in order to achieve a secure fit into the groove.
Note that in the photo, there are extra holes and protrusions from earlier designs. Just ignore them for now.

description.text:
This is a performance of a BCN3D+ single extruder to dual independent extruder.
You will need:
-screews from original design for mounting this mod
-Arduino DUE + RADDS 1.5
-nema 17 for the 2nd X axis
-gt2 20 teeth pulley
-gt2 belt for both x carriage
-another full X carrige (4x LM8 linear bearings, hotend, extruder motor,...), you can print the carriage plate. (next mod will use bowden and smaller carriage)
-Arduino 1.5.5 software
-8x LM8 linear bearings
-1x endstop more
-Another spool support Let me know if any of you have doubts. 01/2017 - Working on repetier firmware
1st version of repetier firmware with dual independent extruder.
You need a tool change script (with firmware download in a .txt) I recomend you simplify3D. Take a look how it works: https://www.facebook.com/print3dprojects/videos/473627216180106/

description.text:
This is a bracket/slide for the bottom of a bathtub door. It keeps the door from swinging out to the inside. The original disintegrated and fell apart. I don't know the brand but it may be Kohler, there may be shower doors that use the same bracket..
The slide fits into a groove at the bottom. The issue is that there is no way to slide something into out our of that groove without removing the frame, which I did not want to do. So this is in 2 parts - the bracket and slide. The slide fits into the back of the bracket and goes on the inside of the groove, holding it in. It is a bit tricky to get in, but easier than taking off all the door framing. Once pushed in the slide locks into place.
The inventor design file is also included.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

35%

Notes: I used PET, but other materials may work as well. The slide for the back is small and needs to be strong, the PET worked well.

description.text:
Added arms to servodummy, setting to -1 gives original TorqueMount, 0 gives no arms, 1... gives number of arms.
Useful for subtractive modeling.

This is a second version of my Lazy Susan Spool Adapter... This time around it should use slightly less filament, fewer screws, and can help with the "ABS shrinkage" by having "fudging factor" leeway by making the mount points actually slots in case of up to 2% shrinkage. Oh and this particular bearing was found on Amazon with Prime shipping. All that's needed is:
  • These parts printed. (Note: The hub is for an IC3D spool... you'll have to customize for your spool dimensions...)
    IC3D hub is 52mm in diameter (Compatible with eSun spools)
     Okay,.. maybe I should work on a customizer for this thing... hold on there...
  • Amazon 4" bearing
  • 4x M4 6mm screws
  • M4 10mm screw
  • 5x M4 nuts
    • I sincerely hope that this would be pretty intuitive in terms of assembly... :)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any.

Infill:

Yes.

Notes: Just print this thing.
OpenSCAD Rocks! I used OpenSCAD! The special function for this project is: "hull()".

comments.text: An issue! For those of you who don't use Thread locker... be aware that you should have your filament un-spool clockwise, otherwise the counter-clockwise action of the hub will pop the m4 nut off the bearing.

description.text:
These are the three essentials to any Dragon Warrior's outfit in the world of Queen's Blade.  Roughly based on Branwen's arena garb.
For the comfort of the cosplayer, apply a contour to the printed items.  Use a heat gun to warm the pieces, flat side-down, against a curved surface.  Once pliant, remove the heat and gently sculpt using your fingers.  Hold in place until they cool and harden. 
This is sort of a work in progress... perhaps by halloween next year, these parts will have sockets where LEDs and other electronics will fit and we'll add more accessories to make the costume more complete.  Stay tuned!
Enjoy!

This is a small Rover robot that my daughter and I designed. She's been learning to program her Arduino. This base is designed to hold 2 standard servos and uses a marble as a caster in the back. It has slots around the sides to mount sensors, bumpers, etc. I didn't add any sort of specific mount for a board though. I didn't want to limit us to a specific platform since we have Arduinos, RaspPis, and Beaglebones.
I left this as a work in progress. I need to do some additional work on the holder for the marble as it's not quite big enough to hold a standard size marble.

I dislike the flat wood backplates that our machines have, and feel like 3DP parts could be stiffer, and more visually pleasing.
I also wanted to try out optimization with Altair Inspire, as I have a demo of it currently. I modeled over optimization, then finished engineered details.
And thus, this "ribcage" for the Z-axis of our machines. You'll have to trim the underside blocks to fit the holes in your plywood, as I modeled them oversize. You'll see in my installation that I broke an arm - it's not a perfect thing but it's GREATLY improved over stock. The Z axis is rock-solid now. Works best with RC-Lohas stainless stiffeners and the spacer blocks for them here on Thingiverse (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:770902) Designed for a 5mm thick plate of glass, but you can move the mech-stop-block down by chopping away at it. It might be within spring-space of being able to take a stock build plate. YMMV.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes: Either print as-is or on its "back." You'll need supports under the whole of the structure if printed upright. Scale by 10! I farked, and it's scaled wrong :P

comments.text: I like how this ended up and I must say that I am fond of optimization techniques and organic/cellular design for stronger parts. Airbus proved that metal 3D printing this way gets stronger parts with less material. With 3D printed parts, the more outer layers we have and the more holes we have (around which the slicers are forced to create perimeters) the stronger the part is.

Using food-safe silicone sealant, a lot of patience, and a good lollipop recipe, you too can have TARDIS shaped lollipops to keep the kids (both big and small) quiet when the new Doctor Who episodes start up again.

You will require -
--Very strong glue (hot glue is only barely good enough)
--Food safe silicone sealant (such as Dap 08641, about $7 a tube)
--Patience
--Rubber/latex gloves
--...
--Sugar
--Corn Syrup
--Cream of Tartar To Make a Mold
  • Print one each of Part1 and Part2.
  • Glue these together with the bottom of the TARDIS-shaped positive flush up against the lollipop-stick-indentation inside the box. This glue must be STRONG!
  • Wearing the gloves, smear food-safe silicone sealant inside the box and over the TARDIS positive. Get it in to all the corners as best you can.
    3a. Try to make this first layer thin - it will help with the silicone curing. Many thin layers are better than one mega-thick layer here!
  • Wait, and let it cure. It will stink of vinegar. Wait a couple of days.
  • Repeat parts 3 and 4 until you've built up the box to the top with sealant.
  • Once it's fully cured, carefully peel your mold out of the box. If you used hot glue, you'll probably peel the positive out of the box, like I did!
  • Let it cure for a while yet, and give it a rinse in water. It will still stink of vinegar.
    • Admire your new TARDIS lollipop mold! The detail is pretty incredible - you'll be able to make out the individual printing lines, but in the final lollipop, it will smooth out quickly. To Make a Lollipop
  • Rinse your mold and carefully dry it.
  • Follow this recipe:
    http://www.exploratorium.edu/cooking/candy/recipe-lollipops.html
    2a. Beware your sugar continuing to heat up after 300 degrees. Take it off the heat and perhaps even pour it into a pyrex jug. Burnt sugar isn't nice.
  • When cooled, peel off the silicone mold. Note - you do not need to oil the silicone mold, it peels off beautifully without, and no-one likes oily lollipops.
    • Other Custom Lollipops
    Of course, the two part mold means you could create a non-TARDIS positive for your lollipop mold shape - anything of that approximate depth, with enough bottom area to attach to the stick is fair game. Nyan Cat?
    Stephen Colbert head?
    Yoda? If you can print it, you can suck it! ;)

comments.text: FYI- Latex gloves can stop the silicone from setting. You should never have it in the room with the silicone. You'll find that it will set much quicker.

Every morning I take a selfie while I am running, like the one shown here in the band shell. I have a HTC One phone that I really like but I needed a way to stand it up. At first I made a somewhat bulky stand out of Lego, and then I modified a failed print of a scaled down building. Finally, I decided to design a minimal stand that would be perfect for my needs: something small and would incorporate the protective flip case. My shots require the camera to be perfectly straight, which is what you get when you slip the phone and case into it. Without the case you get a bit of an angle, which is perfect if you want to keep it on your desk for viewing/periscoping, etc. If you want to see more pictures that I make with this stand, view/follow me @peripheralart on instagram: https://instagram.com/peripheralart/

description.text:
These are 3 different variations I made on replacements for the Koss KSC75 headphone grills. These are famously good for their price, and this is meant as a substitute for the famous "Kramer mod". Instead of drilling holes in your stock grills - print these and go back to stock at will! Note: These are all designed to be sat "upside down" and the tabs allow them to rest on top of the outer case instead of the driver itself (like stock) - but if you remove the tabs it will rest similar to stock. My Impressions:
Stock: reasonably balanced, but muddy sounding
V1: very clear - but overly bright for my tastes
V2: a great compromise between V1 and stock [my choice]
V3: These have kind of a muddy sound to them, but someone might like them.

After losing a bolt handle I decided to make a spare. I ordered some 5mm diameter round rod from MMC and cut to length. I filed a notch similar to the original handle. That gave me a round rod sticking out of the bolt. So I printed a crude handle to make it easier to grip. There isn't much room where the handle inserts into the bolt, so some of the plastic was lost when inserting the rod.
If I lose another handle I will refine this more.

This is a replacement part for a Remington VersaMax magazine tube cap. This is the cap that holds the magazine spring in place. I designed this shorter than the original in the hope that I might fit another shell in the magazine. I also intend to lengthen this design so it can serve as a one piece cap and plug limiting the magazine to two shells for waterfowl hunting.
Note: At the end of the design, I was locking up OpenScad during Preview. Render worked fine so I just avoided the Preview..

The name says it all. The fit is quite snug, but I managed to get my board set with a little wiggling. LxW dimensions are the Apple TV's exactly, the H dimension is a few mm taller to fit the board better. Secure the Pi + Case Bottom with 2.5x5 metric screws (flat headed ones) Recommend running OSMC as your OS. Install OpenVPN + Kodi Repositories (KODI Popcorntime). Welcome to your torrent dream machine.

title: Arduino Uno + SmartThings Arduino Shield Enclosure

description.text: Arduino Uno + SmartThings Arduino Shield Enclosure This enclosure is printed in 2 parts. There is a base component that will allow one to pressure fit (no screws to hold down- strictly a friction fit) an Arduino Uno Development board. Then there are 2 version of the upper cover. One that has flexible tabs modeled in that allow one to press the plastic tabs down to either actuate the PAIR or RESET buttons that are found on top of the SmartThings Arduino Shield. https://shop.smartthings.com/#!/products/smartthings-shield-arduino The other upper cover has not tab cutouts for accessing the buttons on the SmartThings shield and just provide complete coverage. Both upper covers slide over the base and click into place with small tabs at the bottom of the enclosure. This enclosure offers 2 tabs on each corner to facilitate wall mounting.

author: p1neapples

description.text:
After my winter-ready bike-on-the-trainer was kicked out to the basement from a warm spot in front of the TV in the living room, I've realized that there has to be a mobile entertainment setup. Here is a quick solution. The handlebar holder for Nexus 7 (1st gen) tablet. 
It was designed to use with the bike trainer, do not use it while riding!
The STL files are for the left and right holder bars each positioned diagonally to better fit onto the plate. The extra material is printed on both ends to avoid warping, cut it off after it is done. I print it in ABS (PLA seems to be too brittle for this).
The bike handlebar diameter is 32mm, The screws are 6/32, 1 1/2 long. Use soldering iron to dip the nuts into the sockets.
The Nexus 1st gen is thicker than 2nd (its about 10mm thick).
